docs.text: Definition # A group (G, * ) (G, * ) consists of a set G G and a binary operation * * such that G G is closed under * * This means that if g * h g * h belongs to G G for all g, h \in G g, h \in G . Associativity This implies that g_1 * (g_2 * g_3) = (g_1 * g_2) * g_3 g_1 * (g_2 * g_3) = (g_1 * g_2) * g_3 for all g_1, g_2, g_3 \in G g_1, g_2, g_3 \in G . There exists an identity element There exists an element e e such that g * e = e * g = g g * e = e * g = g for all g \in G g \in G . Every element has an inverse. For every element g \in G g \in G , there exists an element h h such that g * h = h * g = e g * h = h * g = e . Some examples of groups are (\mathbb{Z}, +) (\mathbb{Z}, +) , (\mathbb{Z}_0, \times) (\mathbb{Z}_0, \times) . If the group operation is commutative, then we say the group is abelian . The order of the group is the number of elements in the group. |G| |G| . The order of an element g g is the minimum integer n n such that g^n = e g^n = e .

docs.text: Overview # Combinatorics is all about counting. It helps us answer questions such as "In how many different ways can you arrange 10 books on a shelf?" and "In how many ways can you write 42 as a sum of three positive numbers?". Knowing how to count is useful while designing algorithms. It has applications in probability and statistics, as well as graph theory.

docs.text: 1.1 Pigeonhole Principle # The pigeonhole principle is a simple statement, yet it is essential for proving several advanced results in combinatorics. Statement # Theorem If there are n n holes, and n+1 n+1 pigeons, and each pigeon is in some hole, then there exists a hole with at least two pigeons. Proof Suppose all holes have at most one pigeon. Then there are at most n n pigeons. This is a contradiction since we have n+1 n+1 pigeons. Generalized Form # The above statement can be generalized to the following. Theorem If there are n n holes, and rn+1 rn+1 pigeons, and each pigeon is in some hole, then there exists a hole with at least r+1 r+1 pigeons. The proof for this goes along similar lines to the special case of r = 1 r = 1 . Exercises # Exercise You have a drawer full of red socks, blue socks, and yellow socks. You would like a matching pair of socks, but the room is dark so you can't see the colours of the socks. What is the minimum number of socks you need to take out to guarantee you have a matching pair? Exercise What are the minimum number of rooks you must place on an 8 \times 8 8 \times 8 chessboard such that there always exist two rooks that attack each other? Try the same problem with bishops instead of rooks. Exercise Nine numbers are selected from the set \{1, 2, \ldots , 100 \} \{1, 2, \ldots , 100 \} . Show that there exist two numbers whose difference is less than 11. Exercise There are 142857 people who reside in the beautiful town of Mathville. Show that there is a group of 357 residents who share their birthday with each other. Exercise Choose any 5 points inside a square with sides of length 2. Show that there exist two points such that the distance between them is no more than \sqrt{2} \sqrt{2} .
docs.title: 1.1 Pigeonhole Principle

The proofs are collapsed by default for this reason. Hints are present in case of a difficult proof. Same for problems and solutions. Try to solve them on your own before reading the solutions. docs.text: A probability space is a triple (\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P) (\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P) . The set \Omega \Omega is the sample space. It consists of all possible outcomes. An event E E is a subset of \Omega \Omega . \mathcal{F} \mathcal{F} is the set of events. P P is the probability function that assigns to each event in \mathcal{F} \mathcal{F} a value between 0 0 and 1 1 .
